questions.question: 1. In a transverse wave, how do the particles of the medium move compared to the wave's direction?
options: They move in the same direction.
They move up and down while the wave moves sideways.
questions.explanation: Think of a wave on a rope. You shake it up and down, but the wave travels along the rope. The particle motion (up/down) is perpendicular to the wave direction (sideways).

questions.question: 2. What are the high points of a transverse wave called?
questions.explanation: The high points are called crests, just like the top of a wave in the ocean.

questions.question: 3. What are the low points of a transverse wave called?
questions.explanation: The low points are called troughs.

questions.question: 4. Which of the following is the BEST example of a transverse wave?
options: A sound wave traveling through air.
A wave you make by shaking a rope up and down.
A push moving through a slinky.
questions.explanation: A wave on a rope is a classic example. You can see the up-and-down motion creating crests and troughs.

questions.question: 5. Which type of wave is transverse and can travel through empty space?
questions.explanation: Light is an electromagnetic wave, which is transverse. Unlike sound, it doesn't need air or a medium to travel; it can move through a vacuum.

questions.question: 6. What do we call it when the vibrations of a transverse wave are restricted to one plane?
questions.explanation: Polarization is a property of only transverse waves. Polarized sunglasses use this to block out glare by restricting the light waves' vibration direction.

questions.question: 7. What is the maximum distance a particle moves from its rest position in a wave called?
questions.explanation: Amplitude is the height of the wave from the rest position to a crest. A higher amplitude means more energy.

questions.question: 8. The distance from one wave crest to the next is called the...
questions.explanation: Wavelength is the distance between two identical points on consecutive waves, like crest-to-crest or trough-to-trough.

questions.question: 9. Why can't you make a true transverse wave in the air with your hand?
options: Air particles can't push each other sideways to transfer energy up and down.
Transverse waves are only for light.
questions.explanation: Air particles are easily pushed forward and backward (making sound waves), but they can't effectively grip each other to transfer a sideways, up-and-down motion like a rope can.

questions.question: 10. Looking at a transverse wave diagram, how could you identify it?
options: It shows areas squeezed together and spread out.
It looks like a straight line.
It has a repeating pattern of crests and troughs.
It shows particles moving in circles.
questions.explanation: The clearest visual clue for a transverse wave is its pattern of alternating crests (high points) and troughs (low points).
